answers: No, it is never impossible to get credit so long as there are no price controls or quotas. In most of the United States, the impetus for housing is so strong that it's one sector of credit that has nearly no price regulation, price in this case being interest rates. Also, Fannie & Freddie, who ultimately finance most mortgages in the US now require banks to buy back loans if they fail, so banks are only financing the most creditworthy. All is not lost because markets are like rivers if not fully dammed: they find a way through. In your case, you can get a fully-financed mortgage if you're willing to pay interest rates probably double what you could otherwise get in the market with good credit. If the foreclosure process is quick and benefits the lender more in your state, the interest rate will be even lower. Your creditors will most likely be individuals you find at mortgage investment clubs and religious institutions.  If you shop around, you'll be surprised at how low a rate you might get. Also, since the cost of your prospective home is so low, it's very easy for an investor flush with cash and few investments to take a flier on a mother committed to her children who only needs $50,000. The FHA has been vastly expanded, and since your individual credit is clean, there may be a chance to get financing through it, but be prepared for red tape.

According to the World Gold Council (WGC), global gold mining output has increased at an average annual rate of around 1.5% over the past 20 years, from 2,526 tonnes in 1999 to 3,333 tonnes in 2019. This represents an increase of approximately 37,000 tonnes over the past two decades.

As the easy gold has been mined, and cost goes up, there's a point where mines close. But as the price of gold trades at these levels, the mines that couldn't produce at $600 are now opening.

6. Forced savings: Property investment can be a form of forced savings, as property owners are required to make regular mortgage payments

If I am claiming 0 dependents I will get back about $5,000 this year versus breaking even.

prompt:

Lost credit card replaced with new card and new numbers. Credit score affected?[/INST]

Yes, replacing a lost credit card can potentially affect your credit score. When you report a lost or stolen credit card to your issuer, they will typically cancel the old card and issue a new one with a new card number. This can have a temporary impact on your credit score due to the following reasons:

1. Change in credit utilization ratio: Your credit utilization ratio is the amount of credit you're using compared to the total credit available to you. When your card is cancelled and replaced, your credit utilization ratio will increase, which can negatively affect your credit score.
2. Difference in credit history: The old card may have a longer credit history than the new card, which can affect the average age of your credit accounts. Additionally, the new card may not have as much credit history as the old card, which can also impact your score.
3. Changes in credit mix: Your credit mix refers to the variety of credit accounts you have, such as credit cards, loans, and mortgages. When you replace a card, the new card may not have the same type of credit as the old card, which can affect your credit mix.
4. Inquiries: When you apply for a new card or report a lost card, the credit bureaus may consider it an inquiry, which can temporarily ding your credit score.

However, it's important to note that the
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and Member Since year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be merged into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no new tradeline in this scenario.

How is your credit score related to credit utilization?[/INST]
pred:
Credit score and credit utilization are closely related in the world of personal finance. Your credit score is a three-digit number that lenders use to evaluate the risk of lending you money. A higher credit score indicates a lower risk, while a lower score indicates a higher risk. Credit utilization is one of the key factors that affect your credit score.

Credit utilization refers to the amount of available credit you use compared to the amount of credit available to you. In other words, it's the ratio of your outstanding debt to your total credit limits. For example, if you have a credit card with a $10,000 credit limit and you owe $1,000 on that card, your credit utilization is 10%.

The impact of credit utilization on your credit score is as follows:

* Excellent utilization: Using less than 3% of your available credit can significantly improve your credit score.
* Good utilization: Using 3% to 9% of your available credit can also have a positive impact on your credit score.
* Fair utilization: Using 10% to 20% of your available credit may have a neutral impact on your credit score.
* Poor utilization: Using more than 20% of your available credit can negatively impact your credit score.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
Thank you for asking! Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When you buy a stock, the company will pay out dividends to its shareholders, and these dividends are usually taxed as ordinary income. The amount of taxes owed will depend on your individual tax situation and the tax laws in your state.

In the United States, dividends are subject to federal income tax, and you may also be subject to state and local taxes on dividend income. The withheld taxes are typically not included in the dividend quote you receive from your broker. Instead, you will receive a Form 1099-DIV at the end of the year that shows the total amount of dividends you received, including any withheld taxes.

It's important to keep in mind that the withheld tax rate may differ from your actual tax liability, so you may need to pay more or less taxes when you file your tax return. You can use the withheld tax amount as an estimate of your actual tax liability and adjust it on your tax return. If you have any questions or concerns about dividend taxes, you may want to consult with a financial advisor or tax professional.
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
Stop-loss orders are a common risk management strategy used by traders to limit potential losses in their investments. These orders are designed to execute a sell order when the price of an asset drops below a specified level, known as the stop price. The stop price is set by the trader and is typically placed above the current price of the asset.

The safety of using stop-loss orders depends on various factors, including the market conditions, the trader's investment strategy, and the broker's execution policy. Here are some factors to consider:

1. Market volatility: Stop-loss orders are more effective in calm markets than in highly volatile ones. In volatile markets, the stop price may be triggered multiple times, leading to a series of sell orders that can exacerbate the losses.
2. Market gaps: A stop-loss order may not be effective if the market gaps below the stop price. This can occur when there is a sudden and significant price move overnight or during off-hours. In such cases, the stop-loss order may be triggered, but the sale price may be significantly worse than expected.
3. Brokerage execution: The execution policy of the broker can affect the effectiveness of a stop-loss order. Some brokers may fill the stop-loss order at a worse price than expected due to market conditions or liquidity issues.
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

Yes, another tax loss can be used to offset capital gains taxes. This is known as "tax loss harvesting." Tax loss harvesting allows investors to use capital losses to offset capital gains, reducing the amount of taxes owed on the gains.

Here's how it works:

1. Determine your annual capital loss: Calculate the total amount of capital losses from sales of investments during the year.
2. Offset capital gains: Use the capital losses to offset capital gains from other investments sold during the same tax year. This means you won't have to pay taxes on the capital gains portion of your investment returns.
3. Carry forward losses: Any remaining capital losses can be carried forward to future years, where they can be used to offset future capital gains. There is no time limit on how long you can carry forward losses, but you must use them within three years of when they were incurred.
4. Use losses against other income: In addition to offsetting capital gains, you can also use capital losses to reduce other types of income, such as interest income or ordinary income.

It's important to note that there are some limitations and restrictions on tax loss harvesting, including:

* Wash sale rule: If you sell an investment at a loss and buy the same or substantially identical invest
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

A debt collector is allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report under certain circumstances. A hard inquiry occurs when a creditor or debt collector checks your credit report to evaluate your creditworthiness or to collect a debt.

The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) allows debt collectors to access your credit report for the purpose of collecting a debt, as long as they have a legitimate reason for doing so. This means that if you owe a debt to a collection agency, they may check your credit report to assess your financial situation and determine the best course of action for collecting the debt.

However, it's important to note that debt collectors are not allowed to make unnecessary or unwarranted inquiries on your credit report. In other words, they cannot check your credit report without a valid reason or without your consent.

If you believe that a debt collector has made an unauthorized inquiry on your credit report, you can dispute the inquiry with the credit reporting agency and request that it be removed. You can also contact the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) or your state's Attorney General's office for assistance.

In summary, while debt collectors are allowed
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

Many people invest in stock, including mutual funds, and the dividends and capital gains are taxed at lower rates. Individual tax returns that contain no wage income often have very low average tax rates for this reason. However, the investments themselves are continuously paying out their own taxes, or accruing taxes in the form of future tax liability.

pred:
A stop order and a stop limit order are two types of investment orders that are commonly used by traders and investors to manage their investments. While both types of orders are used to limit potential losses or lock in profits, they have some key differences:

A stop order, also known as a "stop loss" order, is an instruction to buy or sell a security when its price reaches a certain level. When the price of the security reaches the specified level, the stop order becomes a market order, which means that it is executed at the current market price. The main purpose of a stop order is to limit potential losses by automatically selling a security when its price drops below a certain level. For example, if an investor buys 100 shares of XYZ stock at $50 per share and thinks the stock may drop in value, they can place a stop order to sell the stock at $40 per share to limit their losses.

A stop limit order, on the other hand, is an order to buy or sell a security when its price reaches a certain level, but only if it can be executed at a specified price or better. In other words, a stop limit order is a limit order that becomes a market order when the price of the security reaches the specified stop price. The main advantage of a stop limit order is that it allows investors to set a specific price at which they want to buy or
answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

This would give the investor the right, but not the obligation, to sell the ETF at a specified price (strike price) at any time before the expiration date.
3. Managing the hedge: Once the hedge has been created, the investor will need to monitor its effectiveness and adjust it as necessary. This may involve adjusting the strike price
answers: In this type of strategy profit is made when the shares go down as your main position is the short trade of the common stock. Yes, there is a converse to dollar-cost-averaging, and it's called "lump-sum investing" or "lump-sum withdrawal." Lump-sum investing involves investing or withdrawing a large sum of money at one time, rather than spreading the investment or withdrawal over time through dollar-cost-averaging.

The main advantage of lump-sum investing is that it allows investors to take advantage of favorable market conditions or to achieve their investment goals quickly. For example, if an investor believes that the stock market is about to experience a significant rally, they may choose to invest a large sum of money all at once to take advantage of the potential gains.

On the other hand, there are also several potential disadvantages to lump-sum investing. One of the main risks is that the investor may miss out on potential gains if the market declines instead of rallying. This is because the investor has invested a large sum of money all at once, rather than spreading it out over time through dollar-cost-averaging.

Interest on security deposits is not explicitly addressed in Michigan law. It is important to note that the landlord must provide written notice to the tenant within 60 days of the move-out date, stating the amount of the security deposit and any damages or unpaid rent that has been deducted. If the landlord fails to provide this notice, they may be liable for interest on the security deposit

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are all financial instruments that allow investors to invest in a company with the possibility of converting their investment into equity at a later date. However, they are not the same thing and have some key differences.

Convertible debt is a type of debt security that can be converted into equity at the issuer's option or at a specific date in the future. This means that the holder of a convertible debt instrument can choose to convert their debt into equity, or the company can force the conversion if certain conditions are met.

Notes, on the other hand, are a type of debt security that has a fixed interest rate and maturity date. Unlike convertible debt, notes do not have an option to convert into equity, and they are typically not convertible into equity at all.

Bonds are another type of debt security that typically have a fixed interest rate and maturity date. Like notes, bonds do not have an option to convert into equity, and they are not typically convertible into equity at all.

Debentures are a type of debt security that is similar to bonds, but they are not backed by assets. Instead, they are backed by the creditworthiness of the issuer, which means that they typically have a higher credit risk than b
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Interest on Amount Exceeding CC Balance?[/INST]
pred:
Interest on an amount exceeding the credit card balance is a common scenario for many cardholders. When this happens, the interest charges are calculated based on the outstanding balance, not the entire amount owed. Here's how it works:

Say you have a credit card balance of $1,000, and you charge an additional $500 to the card. The new balance will be $1,500 ($1,000 + $500). The interest charges will be calculated based on the new balance of $1,500, not the entire amount owed ($2,500).

The interest rate on your credit card is 20% per year. If it takes you 6 months to pay off the additional $500, you will be charged interest on the outstanding balance of $1,500 x 20% = $300. So, your new balance after 6 months will be $1,500 + $300 = $1,800.

It's important to keep in mind that interest charges can add up quickly, especially if you carry a balance on your credit card for an extended period. To avoid paying more interest than necessary, try to pay off your credit card balance in full each month or make frequent payments towards the outstanding balance to reduce the interest charges.
answers: The best answer to this is: Read the fine print on your credit card agreement. What is common, at least in the US, is that you can make any charges you want during a time window.  When the date comes around that your statement balance is calculated, you will owe interest on any amount that is showing up as outstanding in your account.  Example...  To revise the example you gave, let's say Jan 1. your account balance was $0. Jan. 3rd you went out and spent $1,000.  Your account statement will be prepared every XX days... usually 30. So if your last statement was Dec. 27th, you can expect your next statement to be prepared ~Jan.24 or Jan. 27.  To be safe, (i.e. not accrue any interest charges) you will want to make sure that your balance shows $0 when your statement is next prepared.  So back to the example you gave--if your balance showed $1,000... and you paid it off, but then charged $2,000 to it... so that there was now a new set of $2,000 charges in your account, then the bank would begin charging you interest when your next statement was prepared.  Note that there are some cards that give you a certain number of days to pay off charges before accruing interest... it just goes back to my saying "the best answer is read the fine print on your card agreement."

answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there).  Carl Icahn for example is one of those investors in Apple's case [and in many cases!] who put significant pressure, particularly when they were sitting on hundreds of billions of dollars. Ultimately, a (for-profit) corporation's board is tasked with maximizing its shareholder's wealth; as such, it can buy back shares, pay dividends, sell the company, liquidate the company, or expand the company, at its discretion, so long as it can justify to its shareholders that it is still attempting to maximize the value of their holdings.  Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETFwhich manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAVthey go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeemwhich manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discountthey process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

When someone starts a bank, they normally get together a bunch of investors -- perhaps people they know personally, perhaps they sell stock -- to raise initial capital. But most of the money in the bank comes from depositors. Fundamentally, what a bank does is take money from depositors and loan it to borrowers. (Banks also borrow money from other banks and from the government.) They charge the borrowers interest on the loan, and they pay depositors interest on their deposits. The difference between those two interest rates is where the bank gets their profit. Where does the money go when you pay it back? prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How do UK Gilts interest rates and repayments work?[/INST]
pred:
Sure, I'd be happy to help you understand how UK Gilts interest rates and repayments work!

A UK Gilt is a type of government bond issued by the UK Treasury to raise funds from investors. When you buy a Gilt, you are essentially lending money to the government for a fixed period of time (known as the "maturity date") in exchange for a fixed rate of interest (known as the "coupon rate").

The interest rate on a Gilt is set at the time of issue and remains fixed for the life of the bond. The coupon rate is paid semi-annually, which means that the government pays you interest every six months until the bond matures.

For example, let's say you buy a 10-year Gilt with a coupon rate of 2%. Every six months, the government will pay you 2% of the bond's face value, so if the bond has a face value of 1,000, you will receive 20 in interest every six months.

The repayment of the principal amount at maturity is also fixed, which means that when the bond matures, you will receive the full 1,000 back that you invested.

It's worth noting that the interest rates offered on Gilts are generally lower than those offered on other types of invest
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. 100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

For tax purposes, gift giving is typically considered to occur on the date when the gift is transferred or delivered to the recipient. This means that gifts given during a given tax year, which runs from January 1st to December 31st, are considered to be part of that year's gift giving.

In general, cash gifts, stocks, bonds, and other securities are considered to be taxable gifts and are subject to annual gift tax limits. For the 2022 tax year, the annual gift tax exclusion is $15,000 per recipient, per donor. However, it's important to note that not all gifts are considered taxable. For example, gifts that are made directly to a charity or organization for religious, educational, or medical purposes are generally not considered taxable gifts. Additionally, gifts that are made in the form of "direct payments" to a medical provider or insurance company for the benefit of the recipient are also not considered taxable gifts.

This is important as the annual gift exclusion is just that "Annual". 2. Expectation of near-term price movements: If you expect the price of the underlying asset to move significantly in the near term, buying options at the bid price or below can help you profit from the expected price move. answers: This sometimes happens to me. It depends on how liquid the option is. Normally what I see happening is that the order book mutates itself around my order. I interpret this to mean that the order book is primarily market makers. They see a retail investor (me) come in and, since they don't have any interest in this illiquid option, they back off. Some other retail investor (or whatever) steps in with a market order, and we get matched up. I get a fill because I become the market maker for a brief while. On highly liquid options, buy limits at the bid tend to get swallowed because the market makers are working the spread. With very small orders (a contract or two) on very liquid options, I've had luck getting quick fills in the middle of the spread, which I attribute to MM's rebalancing their holdings on the cheap, although sometimes I like to think there's some other anal-retentive like me out there that hates to see such a lopsided book. :) I haven't noticed any particular tendency for this to happen more with puts or calls, or with buy vs sell transactions. For a while I had a suspicion that this was happening with strikes where IV didn't match IV of other strikes, but I never cared enough to chase it down as it was a minor part of my overall P/L.

answers: The price of the last trade... Is the price of the last trade. It indicates what one particular buyer and seller agreed upon. An average of trades across a sufficiently large number of transactions might indicate a rough consensus about the value of a stock, but transactions will be clustered around that average and the average itself moves over time. Investing in dividend-yielding stocks using money borrowed from a margin account can be a potentially lucrative strategy, but it's important to carefully consider the risks involved.

When you invest in dividend-yielding stocks, you are essentially buying shares in companies that have a history of distributing a portion of their profits to shareholders in the form of dividends. These dividends can provide a steady stream of income for investors, which can help offset the risk of investing in the stock market.

Using a margin account to borrow money to invest in dividend-yielding stocks can amplify the potential returns on your investment, but it also increases the risk of losing money. With a margin account, you are borrowing money from a broker to buy more shares than you could otherwise afford, which means you have to pay interest on the borrowed funds. This can significantly reduce the returns on your investment, especially if the stock price falls.

It's important to note that the dividend yield of a stock is not the only factor to consider when evaluating a potential investment. You should also consider other factors such as the company's financial health, growth prospects, and competitive position. A company with a high dividend yield may not necessarily be the best investment if it has a weak financial position or is facing significant headwinds in
answers: In addition to the other answers, here's a proper strategy that implements your idea: If the options are priced properly they should account for future dividend payments, so all other things aside, a put option that is currently at the money should be in the money after the dividend, and hence more expensive than a put option that is out of the money today but at the money after the dividend has been paid. The unprotected futures (if priced correctly) should account for dividend payments based on the dividend history and, since maturing after the payment, should earn you (you sell them) less money because you deliver the physical after the dividend has been paid. The protected ones should reflect the expected total return value of the stock at the time of maturity (i.e. the dividend is mentally calculated into the price), and any dividend payments that happen on the way will be debited from your cash (and credited to the counterparty). Now that's the strategy that leaves you with nearly no risk (the only risk you bear is that the dividend isn't as high as you expected).  But for that comfort you have to pay premiums. If so, do the trade.

prompt:

Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, the wash sale rules are different for stocks and other investment vehicles such as exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and mutual funds. The wash sale rule is a provision in the United States tax law that aims to prevent investors from claiming a tax loss on an investment without actually realizing a loss.

For stocks, the wash sale rule states that if an investor sells a stock at a loss and repurchases the same or substantially identical stock within 30 days before or after the sale, the loss is disallowed for tax purposes. This is because the investor is deemed to have Still owned the stock and the sale is considered a wash sale. However, if the investor waits more than 30 days after the sale before repurchasing the stock, the loss can be claimed for tax purposes.

On the other hand, for ETFs and mutual funds, the wash sale rule is slightly different. These investments are considered "letonnaires", meaning that they are not subject to the 30-day waiting period requirement. However, if an investor sells a mutual fund or ETF and purchases a substantially identical one within 30 days, the loss may still be disallowed for tax purposes if the mutual fund or ETF is part of a "wash sale" basket. This basket includes a
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code  1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical."  Last month, I wrote an article, Tax Loss Harvesting, which analyses the impact of taking losses each year. I study the 2000's which showed an average loss of 1% per year, a 9% loss for the decade. Tax loss harvesting made the decade slightly positive, i.e. an annual boost of approx 1%.

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing, although they are both important metrics used in real estate investment analysis.

Capitalization rate, also known as cap rate, is the ratio of net operating income (NOI) to property value. It measures the return on investment for a real estate property based on the income it generates. The capitalization rate is calculated by dividing the NOI by the property's value, and it represents the annual return on investment as a percentage. For example, if a property generates $100,000 in NOI and is worth $1 million, the capitalization rate would be 10%.

Net profit margin, on the other hand, is a financial metric used to measure a company's profitability. It represents the percentage of profit earned relative to the total revenue generated by a business. Net profit margin is calculated by dividing the company's net income by its total revenue, and it represents the percentage of revenue that is left over after all costs of doing business have been deducted. For example, if a company generates $100,000 in revenue and has total costs of $60,000, the net profit margin would be 40% ($40,000 in net income / $100,000 in revenue).

While both capital

prompt:

How much is one lot of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
A "lot" in the forex market typically refers to a standardized unit of trade, which is typically set by the interbank market and is used by brokers to quote and trade currencies. The size of a lot can vary depending on the currency pair being traded, but it is generally standardized across most brokers and markets.

For the EUR/USD currency pair, one lot is equal to 100,000 units of the base currency (Euro) divided by the quote currency (US Dollar). This means that if you want to trade 1 lot of EUR/USD, you are buying or selling 100,000 Euros and selling or buying 100,000 US Dollars.

It's worth noting that lots are a way to standardize trades and make them easier to manage for traders and brokers. Trading in larger lots can offer better liquidity and tighter spreads, but it also requires more capital to trade. For example, if you want to trade 0.1 lots of EUR/USD (which is equivalent to 10,000 Euros), you will need to have $10,000 in your trading account to cover the transaction costs.

In summary, one lot of EUR/USD is
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, restricted stock units (RSUs) can be taxed as long-term capital gains (LTCG) depending on the specific circumstances. RSUs are a type of equity compensation that represents an owner's right to receive a specified number of shares of company stock at a later date. When an RSU vests, the holder receives the underlying shares of stock, and the gain or loss on the sale of those shares is taxed as capital gains.

Generally, RSUs are taxed as ordinary income when they vest, with the amount of the tax liability depending on the fair market value (FMV) of the underlying shares at the time of vesting. However, if the RSUs are held for more than one year before they are sold, they may be eligible for long-term capital gains treatment.

To qualify for LTCG treatment, the RSUs must be held for at least one year after the date they vest. If the RSUs are held for more than one year, the gain on their sale is characterized as LTCG, which is taxed at a lower rate than ordinary income. The LTCG rate is currently 0%, 15%, or 20%, depending on the taxpayer's taxable income and other factors.

It's worth noting that the tax treatment of RSUs can be complex

prompt:

Is it a bet on price fluctuations and against the house?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, a bet on a sports game in a casino is considered a form of gambling, and it is indeed a bet on price fluctuations, albeit with some added complexities. In a casino, the odds are set by the house, and the bettor is placing a wager against the house.

The house sets the odds for each game based on the probability of the event occurring. For example, in a football game, the house might set the odds of a team winning at 10 to 11, meaning that the team is expected to have a 52.7% chance of winning (10/11). The house profits by collecting a commission, known as the vigorish or juice, on each losing bet.

When a bettor places a wager on a sports game, they are essentially betting that the outcome will differ from the odds set by the house. For example, if they bet on a team to win, they are hoping that the team will win the game and therefore beat the odds set by the house. The bettor will receive a payout if their bet wins, and they will lose their bet if they lose.

It's worth noting that some sportsbooks may offer more favorable odds to attract more bettors, while others may offer less favorable odds to protect their profit margins

It is also possible to have such a contract be settled in the underlying (if the cash value is appropriate, then the cash settlement can be used to purchase the underlying directly, if necessary).  Physical delivery was predominant until the last few decades.  Most traders, as opposed to hedgers or strategics, are going to prefer cash-settled contracts as opposed to physical delivery. The cost charged to one contracting party should be set by the dealer in relation to prices being charged to parties making the opposite, matching bet (in this way, brokers are following market price, while traders are setting it). Is it a bad idea to buy a motorcycle with a lien on it?[/INST]

Buying a motorcycle with a lien on it can have both pros and cons, depending on your financial situation and goals. A lien is a loan or financing agreement that is secured by the motorcycle itself, meaning the lender has the right to repossess the vehicle if you default on payments.

Pros of buying a motorcycle with a lien:

1. Affordability: A lien can make the motorcycle more affordable for you, as you may be able to borrow money at a lower interest rate than you would be able to get on a personal loan.
2. Lower upfront costs: With a lien, you may not have to pay as much money upfront as you would with a traditional loan.
3. Credit building: Making timely payments on a lien can help you establish or improve your credit score, which can be beneficial for future financing options.

Cons of buying a motorcycle with a lien:

1. Potential for negative equity: If the motorcycle depreciates in value faster than you can pay off the lien, you may end up owing more on the loan than the vehicle is worth. This is known as negative equity, and it can make it difficult to sell or trade the motorcycle in the future.
2. Limited flexibility: With a lien on the motorcycle, you
answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

What is the meaning of short selling or going short a stock?[/INST]
pred:
Short selling, also known as going short, is a financial strategy in which an investor sells a stock that they do not own with the expectation of buying it back at a lower price to realize a profit. This is essentially the opposite of buying a stock, where an investor purchases a stock they believe will increase in value.

In short selling, the investor borrows the stock from a broker or another investor and sells it at the current market price. The investor then waits for the stock price to fall, at which point they can buy the stock back at the lower price and return it to the lender, pocketing the difference as profit.

Short selling can be a high-risk strategy, as there is no limit to how much the stock price can rise, potentially resulting in unlimited losses. However, it can also be a valuable tool for hedging against potential losses in a long positions or for taking advantage of market inefficiencies.

It's important to note that short selling is only available for stocks that are traded on a public exchange and is subject to various regulatory restrictions, such as the uptick rule and the wash sale rule. Additionally, short sellers are required to have a margin account and maintain enough capital to cover the potential losses of their short positions.

In summary, short selling is a financial strategy that
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

A tender offer is a financial transaction in which a company or an investor makes a public announcement to purchase a certain number of shares of another company's stock at a specific price. The price offered in a tender offer is typically lower than the current market price of the stock. There are several reasons why a tender offer may be less than the market price:

1. Cost savings: The tendering party may aim to buy the shares at a lower price to save on purchase costs. This can be particularly attractive if the company has a large stake in the target company and can benefit from buying the shares at a lower price.
2. Risk reduction: By purchasing shares at a lower price, the tendering party can reduce the risk of owning the shares at a higher price. If the market price of the target company's stock were to fall after the tender offer, the tendering party would still purchase the shares at the lower price, potentially avoiding significant losses.
3. Influence over the target company: A tender offer can be used as a means to gain influence over the target company. By purchasing a significant amount of shares, the tendering party can exert pressure on the target company's management to adopt certain policies or strategies that align with its interests.
4. Anticipation of future price movements: The tendering party may anticipate that the market price of the target company's stock
answers: As an addition to Chris Rea's excellent answer, these tender offers are sometimes made specifically to cast doubt on the current market price. For instance, a large public company that contracts with a smaller supplier or service company, also public, might make a tender offer below market price. The market will look at this price and the business relationship, and wonder what the larger company knows about the smaller one that they don't. Now, what happens when investors lose confidence in a stock? They sell it, supply goes up, demand goes down, and the price drops. The company making the tender offer can then get its shares either way; directly via the offer, or on the open market. This is, however, usually not successful beyond the very short term, and typically only works because the company making a tender offer is the 800-pound gorilla, which can dictate its own terms with practically anyone else it meets. Such offers are also very closely watched by the SEC; if there's any hint that the larger company is acting in a predatory manner, or that its management is using the power and information of the company to profit themselves, the strategy will backfire as the larger company finds itself the target of SEC and DoJ legal proceedings.

answers: Most people will never need to pay federal gift taxes. The federal gift taxes start after giving away 5.34 million over the course of your life. There are only two states that I know of which impose state gift taxes (Connecticut and Minnesota); in Connecticut, you need to start paying taxes if the lifetime value of your gifts exceed two million. In Minnesota, it starts at 1 million.  The federal tax is paid for by the person making the gift, unless other arrangements are made. There is an annual exclusion amount of approximately $14,000. Instead, you can claim an exemption. Since most people don't exceed that amount, its rare to ever pay taxes even when exceeding the annual exclusion amount. The annual exclusion amount is adjusted each year for inflation.

The U.S. government cannot retroactively tax gains made earlier in the fiscal year. The U.S. tax code is based on a "forward-looking" approach, which means that taxes are assessed on income earned in the current tax year, rather than on income earned in previous years.

This is known as the "accrual basis" of taxation, which means that taxes are calculated based on the income that has been earned during the tax year, rather than on the income that was earned in previous years. This approach is used to ensure that individuals and businesses are taxed on their current income, rather than on income that was earned in previous years.

There are some exceptions to this general rule, however. For example, the U.S. government does allow for the carryover of net operating losses (NOLs) from one tax year to the next. This means that if a business has an NOL in one tax year, it can carry that loss over to future tax years and use it to reduce its taxable income in those years.

Additionally, the U.S. government does allow for the use of "examples" in certain situations. An "example" is a one-time adjustment to a taxpayer's income that is allowed in a specific tax year, and is intended to reflect a change in the taxpayer's income that occurred in a previous

This shift has led to increased diversification in the Swiss economy, reducing the historical reliance on exports and the value of the CHF.

prompt:

What is the opposite of Economic Bubble? [/INST]
pred:
The opposite of an economic bubble is a stable and sustainable economic growth. An economic bubble is a situation where asset prices rise rapidly and unsustainably, fueled by excessive speculation and herd mentality. It is characterized by a rapid increase in asset prices, followed by a sudden collapse, leading to widespread financial losses.

On the other hand, a stable and sustainable economic growth is characterized by a gradual increase in asset prices, fueled by underlying fundamentals such as strong economic growth, low inflation, and sound financial management. This type of economic growth is more likely to be supported by a robust economy, with strong corporate profits, low unemployment, and a stable financial system.

It is important to note that there is no clear definition of a "stable and sustainable" economic growth, as it can vary depending on the specific economic conditions and the expectations of market participants. However, some common characteristics of a stable and sustainable economic growth include:

1. Slow and steady growth: A stable economic growth is characterized by a slow and steady increase in asset prices, rather than a rapid and unsustainable rise.
2. Underlying fundamentals: A stable economic growth is fueled by underlying fundamentals such as strong economic growth, low inflation, and sound financial management, rather than speculation and herd ment
answers: The opposite of an economic bubble is a bubble burst :p! Jokes aside though, an economic bubble occurs when the economy is in bull market mode and asset prices are growing very fast. It's usually measured by ratio's like price to earnings and the levels of various market indices. So, the opposite would be when valuations are falling very fast or are very low, and price to earnings ratios are low.  This condition is usually a recession. A recession is a market slowdown, generally after a bubble bursts, and severe recessions can become depressions if they last long enough (Great Depression, 1930s).  A bubble is not necessarily negative - stock prices usually rise a lot so paper wealth is greatly magnified. If you can get out in time, you're golden. Similarly, a recession isn't bad for everyone. Some investors keep large amounts of cash waiting for recessions so they can "buy low, sell high". For most people, however, recessions are negative because unemployment increases and some people get fired, and the economy slows down. Asset prices have fallen so their investments are worth less than they used to be (on paper), and people mainly have to bide it out until the market starts growing again.

7. Signature: The payor must sign the check to authorize the transfer of funds.
8. MICR line: The Magnetic Ink Character Recognition (MICR) line is located at the bottom of the check and contains the routing number and account number of the payor's bank. This information is used to process the check through the electronic banking network.
9. Vertical

prompt:

What does a Dividend will not be quoted ex mean?[/INST]
pred:
A dividend "will not be quoted ex" refers to a situation where a company decides not to pay out a dividend to its shareholders. This means that the company will not distributing any portion of its profits to its shareholders, either in the form of a cash dividend or a stock dividend.

When a company decides not to pay a dividend, it will typically provide a notice to its shareholders stating that the dividend will not be quoted ex, which means that the dividend will not be included in the company's stock price. This notice is usually given in the company's financial reports or in a separate communication to shareholders.

There are several reasons why a company may decide not to pay a dividend. Some of the most common reasons include:

1. Conservation of cash: The company may choose to retain its profits instead of distributing them to shareholders in order to conserve cash for future investments or to pay off debt.
2. Changes in financial performance: The company may have experienced a decline in profits or a decrease in cash flow, which makes it difficult to pay a dividend.
3. Strategic reasons: The company may choose not to pay a dividend in order to reinvest its profits in the business or to pursue other growth opportunities.
4. Tax implications
answers: One occastion where "will not be quoted ex" is used is when a corporate action is occurring such as a spin-off.  In such a case, the rights to, and the spin-off itself may be quoted separately on the home country exchange.  However, if the company is based abroad, it may not be worth the expense for them to have an additional securities listing on the local (US) exchange. For example:  In November 2016, Yamana Gold (TSX: YRI, NYSE: AUY) announced it will have an initial public offering of a spin-off (Brio Gold, to be listed on TSX as BRIO).  Existing shareholders received a right to one share of the spin-off for every 16 shares they held of YRI (or AUY).  These rights were separately traded in advance of the IPO of the spin-off on TSX under "YRI.RT", but the prospectus they stated that the rights "will not be quoted ex" on NYSE, i.e. there was no separate listing on NYSE for these rights. The wording seems counter-intuitive, but I suspect that is the attorneys who were preparing the prospectus used those specific words as they may have a very specific meaning (e.g. from a statute or previous case).

answers: In most jurisdictions, both the goods (raw materials) and the service (class) are being "sold" to the customer, who is the end user and thus the sale is subject to sales tax. prompt:

What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transferred or sold to another party through a legal document, such as a transfer agent or registrar. Negotiable securities are typically used in the raising of capital by corporations, governments, or other organizations, and they offer a way for investors to buy and sell shares in these issuers. Examples of negotiable securities include stocks, bonds, and certificates of deposit (CDs).

Negotiable securities are closely related to derivatives, which are financial instruments that derive their value from an underlying asset or market event. Derivatives can take many forms, including options, futures, and swaps. These instruments are negotiable, meaning that they can be traded or sold to another party through a market exchange or over-the-counter (OTC) market.

The connection between negotiable securities and derivatives lies in the way they are used to manage risk. Negotiable securities, such as stocks and bonds, are typically used by investors to generate passive income through regular interest payments or dividends. However, these instruments are not as flexible as derivatives when it comes to managing risk. For example, investors cannot easily hedge against changes in interest rates or market volatility using a bond.

Derivatives, on the other hand, offer a wide range of risk management
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.

prompt:

How does a TFSA work? Where does the interest come from?[/INST]
pred:
A Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) is a type of savings account that allows you to set aside money tax-free. It's an Ott savings vehicle that provides tax benefits to individuals in Canada. Here's how a TFSA works and where the interest comes from:

Contributions: You can contribute up to a maximum amount each year to a TFSA, which is set by the Canadian government. The contribution limit for 2022 is $6,000, and you can carry over any unused contribution room from previous years.

Growth: The money in your TFSA grows tax-free, meaning you don't pay taxes on the investment earnings or capital gains. This means that you won't pay taxes on any interest, dividends, or capital gains made on your investments within your TFSA.

Withdrawals: You can withdraw money from your TFSA at any time, and there are no taxes payable on the withdrawals. However, you can only withdraw funds that you've contributed to your TFSA, and you can't withdraw more than your annual contribution limit.

Interest: The interest earned on investments within a TFSA is tax-free. This means that you won't pay taxes on the interest earned on your investments, such as stocks
answers: As to where the interest comes from: The same place it comes from in other kinds of savings accounts. The bank takes the money you deposit and invests it elsewhere, traditionally by lending it out to others (hence the concept of a "savings and loan" bank). They make a profit as long as the interest they give for "borrowing" from you, plus the cost of administering the savings accounts and loans, is less than the interest they charge for lending to others. No, they don't have to pay you interest -- but if they didn't, you'd be likely to deposit your funds at another bank which did. Their ideal goal is to pay as little as possible without losing depositors, while charging as much as possible without losing borrowers. (yeah, I know, typo corrected) Why do they get higher interest rate than they pay you? Mostly because your deposits and interest are essentially guaranteed, whereas the folks they're lending to may be late paying or default on those loans. As with any kind of investment, higher return requires more work and/or higher risk, plus (ususally) larger reserves so you can afford to ride out any losses that do occur.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Credit Card Purchase - 'it is the bank's money no[t] yours' ?[/INST]
pred:
When you use a credit card to make a purchase, it is not necessarily the bank's money that you are using. While it is true that the bank provides the credit card and sets the terms of the credit, the money you spend with your credit card is actually yours to spend.

Here's the thing: when you use a credit card, you are borrowing money from the bank to make the purchase. The bank extends credit to you, allowing you to make the purchase now and pay back the amount borrowed, plus interest, over time. In this sense, it can be thought of as your money, even though you are borrowing it from the bank.

However, it's important to understand that the bank does not actually give you money when you use your credit card. Instead, the bank simply agrees to let you use its money for a particular purchase, and you promise to pay back the amount borrowed, plus interest, at a later date.

So, while it is not strictly accurate to say that the bank's money is yours when you use a credit card, it is important to remember that you are effectively borrowing money from the bank to make a purchase. It's important to use credit cards responsibly and make timely payments to avoid accumulating debt and interest charges.

Your exact rights will vary by bank, but mostly they need to follow the guidelines set by the Credit Card company - and you do need to be a bit careful - if you received goods which were fake or a dispute arises you may be up for shipping the goods back to the merchant - and you have a limited - but reasonable time - in which to make the dispute. If a put seller closes early, it means that the seller has decided to sell the underlying asset at the strike price before the expiration date of the option contract. This happens when the market price of the asset is lower than the strike price, and the seller wants to limit their potential losses.

When a put seller closes early, the buyer of the put option will have several options:

1. Exercise the option: If the buyer of the put option wants to benefit from the lower market price of the underlying asset, they can exercise the option and sell the asset at the strike price. This means that the buyer will sell the asset at a higher price than its current market price, which can lead to a profit.
2. Let the option expire worthless: If the market price of the underlying asset is higher than the strike price at expiration, the put option will expire worthless. In this case, the buyer will not make any money from the option, but they will not lose anything either.
3. Sell the option: If the buyer of the put option does not want to exercise the option or let it expire worthless, they can sell the option to another buyer at a price that reflects the time value and underlying asset price.

It's important to note that when a put seller closes early, the buyer of the put option
answers: An option is freely tradable, and all options (of the same kind) are equal. If your position is 0 and you sell 1 option, your new position in that option is -1. If the counterparty to your trade buys or sells more options to close, open, or even reopen their position afterwards, that doesn't matter to your position at all. Of course there's also the issue with American and European Options. European Options expire at their due date, but American Options expire at their due date or at any time before their due date if the holder decides they expire. With American Options, if a holder of an American Option decides to exercise the option, someone who is short the same option will be assigned as the counterparty (this is usually random). Expiry is after market close, so if one of your short American Options expires early, you will need to reopen the position the next day. Keep in mind dividends for slightly increased complexity. American and European Options do not in any way refer to the continents they are traded on, or to the location of the companies. These terms simply describe the expiry rules.

pred:
High trading volume in a stock is indicative of increased activity and interest in the stock. It means that there are more buyers and sellers participating in the market, driving up the stock's price. High volume can be a good or bad thing depending on the reasons behind it.

A good sign of high trading volume is if it is driven by positive market sentiment, such as a company's strong earnings report or a positive outlook for the industry. In this case, high volume indicates that investors are confident in the stock's potential for future growth and are buying or selling accordingly.

On the other hand, high trading volume can also be a sign of market manipulation or insider trading, which can lead to unstable or unfair prices. In this case, high volume may indicate a lack of transparency or fairness in the market, and investors should be cautious.

Another potential negative sign of high trading volume is if it is driven by short-term market sentiment or speculation, rather than fundamental value. If the volume is high due to a temporary market fad or hype, it may not reflect the stock's intrinsic value or long-term potential.

In summary, high trading volume can be a good thing if it is driven by positive market sentiment and reflects confidence in a company's growth potential. However, it can
answers: In general, liquidity is a good thing, because it means it is easy for you to buy or sell a stock.   Since high liquidity stocks have a lot of trading, the bid-ask spreads tend to be pretty low.  That means you can go into the market and trade easily and cheaply at just about any time.  For low liquidity stocks, the bid-ask spreads can get pretty high, so it can make it hard or expensive to get into or out of your trades. On the flip side, everyone pays attention to high liquidity stocks, so it's harder to get an edge in your trading.  For a company like Microsoft there are 30-50 full time analysts that cover them, thousands of professional traders and millions of investors in general all reading the same new articles and looking through the same financials as you.  But in low liquidity stocks, there probably aren't any analysts, a few professional traders and maybe a few thousand total investors, so it can be easier to find a good buy (or sell). In general, high liquidity doesn't mean that everyone is selling or everyone is buy, it just means everyone is trading.
